author: barnabasbusa
content:
We have seen quite some releases from each client team even in the last week. Some are criticial, some aren't. Is there a reason client teams decide to push out an update so close to the mainnet fork date? I'd just prefer if client teams would be a bit more cautious regarding last minute releases, as they might introduce unexpected regression, that couldn't have been tested so close to the fork date. 

I understand that some bumps are minor, but its still a bit worrisome - from the testing point of view.  I'd much prefer to have these small fixes rolled out potentially once the fork transition is completed, that way we can be sure that the code tested with shadowforks and previous devnets is the code that will be rolled out on mainnet.

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: I think it's a consequence of shorter hardforks. I don't know how other teams are feeling, but we kept improving the codebase after the official mainnet release for Fusaka. I guess what is happening is an acceptable situation given tight schedules.

author: barnabasbusa
content: Imo only critical releases should be pushed between the date of announcement of releases and mainnet fork date.

content: I'm not saying that we shouldn't have releases post the announcement, but shipping unrelated features seems risky.
